G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319B.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19B and applicable provisions governing civil actions within the jurisdictional amount of the Boston Municipal Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 8.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Municipal Court, Roxbury Division, because the Premises are located in Roxbury, Massachusetts, and the cause of action arose in this Division. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 2, 8.

G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 111.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been the landlord and person in control of the Premises, including Plaintiff’s unit, within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 111.

State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.raw_text: State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had a duty to maintain the Premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including requirements relating to water penetration, moisture, structural integrity, and habitability.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease in Massachusetts contains a covenant that the tenant shall have the quiet enjoyment of the premises.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., landlords must keep residential premises in compliance with minimum standards of fitness for human habitation.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from serious interference with the use, occupancy, and beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises caused by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s control. See, e.g., Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when the tenant is very substantially deprived of the beneficial use of the premises by serious interference caused by activities the landlord created and had the right to control, even without an intent to evict. The court explains that quiet enjoyment is violated where substantial interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, and applies that rule to the lounge noise the landlords could control. This directly matches the proposition that quiet enjoyment protects tenants from serious interference caused by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s control.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.raw_text: Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997) (persistent code violations and failure to repair can breach quiet enjoyment)
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct substantial code violations and conditions threatening health or safety can constitute an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997) (persistent code violations and failure to repair can breach quiet enjoyment); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes that a landlord’s failure to repair known hazardous conditions (including code-type defects) can constitute a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment when the landlord is at least negligent. In explaining the standard under G.L. c. 186, § 14, the court cites prior cases where failure to repair serious defects after notice breached quiet enjoyment and then clarifies that, for lead paint, a landlord who has notice or reason to know of the presence of lead and fails to take appropriate corrective measures may be liable under § 14. That directly supports the proposition that uncorrected substantial, health‑threatening code violations can amount to unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment, though the case emphasizes the need for landlord fault (negligence) rather than strict liability.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon… Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth.… Dorgan v. Loukas…. Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…. [T]o obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct substantial code violations and conditions threatening health or safety can constitute an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997) (persistent code violations and failure to repair can breach quiet enjoyment); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide required heat—an essential service governed by the State Sanitary Code—“seriously impairs” the premises and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Although the opinion focuses specifically on lack of heat rather than a broader list of code violations, it clearly treats this serious code-related condition as an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment, directly supporting the proposition in context.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “The tenant correctly argues that the judge erred in declaring that the landlords’ financial inability to purchase oil constituted a defense to the quiet enjoyment claim. A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment…. Thus… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 787–88 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Serious water infiltration, chronic dampness, and conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, particularly when left unremedied after notice, constitute a substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 787–88 (1994); McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 308–09 (1977).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to correct serious State Sanitary Code violations—after notice—constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, because such conditions substantially impair the value of the premises as a dwelling. While the facts emphasize inadequate heat, hot water, and vermin rather than “water infiltration” specifically, the court’s reasoning is expressly about unsanitary, code-violating conditions substantially interfering with use and enjoyment, which directly supports the stated proposition in general form.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 308–09 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.proposition: Serious water infiltration, chronic dampness, and conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, particularly when left unremedied after notice, constitute a substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 787–88 (1994); McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 308–09 (1977).
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.support_reasoning: The McKenna opinion is about damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability based on State Sanitary Code violations; it does not discuss or apply the covenant of quiet enjoyment or use that term. While the court recognizes that serious and major code violations can materially diminish the tenant’s use and enjoyment and warrant substantial rent abatement, it does so under warranty-of-habitability doctrine, not quiet enjoyment. Thus it does not directly support the specific proposition that such conditions constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt:
“On remand, the judge found that McKenna’s tenancy started in June, 1972… Because he found that the major defects for which he awarded damages existed at the outset of the tenancy, he computed damages from that date…

We also agree with the judge that McKenna is not entitled to receive damages for the minor code violations in this case… On the other hand, there may be instances in which minor violations in conjunction with major violations or a multitude of minor violations with a cumulative effect on habitability should be taken into consideration in reducing rent… In all cases, however, the trial court is given broad discretion to determine whether defects constitute material breaches of the warranty of habitability.”

Aubin v. Susi, 331 Mass. 140, 142\u20134.proposition: The landlord’s knowledge of a defective condition and failure to take appropriate action can give rise to liability for breach of quiet enjoyment where the condition substantially impairs the tenant’s use and enjoyment. See, e.g., Aubin v. Susi, 331 Mass. 140, 142–43 (1954); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994).
Aubin v. Susi, 331 Mass. 140, 142\u20134.case_name: Sullivan v. Committee on Rules of the House of Representatives
Aubin v. Susi, 331 Mass. 140, 142\u20134.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns whether a legislative committee employee has civil service/veterans’ tenure protection under G.L. c. 30, § 9A and related provisions. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, defects in leased premises, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Citing Aubin v. Susi for the proposition about landlord liability for breach of quiet enjoyment is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by this decision.
Aubin v. Susi, 331 Mass. 140, 142\u20134.relevant_excerpt: "We do not think that the position of director of fiscal affairs for the committee on ways and means of the House of Representatives is 'an office or position in the service of the commonwealth not classified under said chapter thirty-one' within the meaning of G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 30, § 9A, as appearing in St. 1947, c. 242. We are unable to discover that the Legislature here has manifested the most unlikely intention that one General Court, or one branch thereof, shall commit a succeeding General Court, or one branch thereof, by employing an individual for three years in the service of one of its committees."

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The landlord’s knowledge of a defective condition and failure to take appropriate action can give rise to liability for breach of quiet enjoyment where the condition substantially impairs the tenant’s use and enjoyment. See, e.g., Aubin v. Susi, 331 Mass. 140, 142–43 (1954); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s knowledge of a seriously impairing condition and failure to take appropriate action can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. The court states that if the landlord “failed to take any action” (or took inadequate action) to remove persons engaged in unlawful activity, and their presence seriously interfered with the tenants’ use of the premises, the landlord may be liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. That directly matches the proposition that knowledge plus inaction regarding a substantially impairing condition can give rise to such liability.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment…. We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures…to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–02 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Failure to comply may also support a claim for interference with quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 201–02 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is entirely about breach of the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement when the landlord fails to provide heat and hot water. It does not discuss, analyze, or even mention a claim for interference with quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. While the same factual failures (e.g., lack of heat) might also support a quiet enjoyment claim in other cases, this decision itself is authority only on warranty of habitability and related rent remedies, not on quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), we found that social changes in landlord-tenant relations and legislative changes in landlord obligations and tenant remedies were inconsistent with medieval notions of the lease as a conveyance of property… ‘[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises.’ … We held that a tenant is entitled to a rent abatement… during the period that an apartment remains uninhabitable after the landlord has notice of the defects.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment exists independently of the tenant’s obligation to pay rent; a tenant’s minor or cured default does not excuse a landlord from complying with G.L. c. 186, § 14 and maintaining habitable conditions. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–200 (1973).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from Justice Quirico’s separate concurrence/dissent, not the majority, and it does not adopt the rule that the covenant of quiet enjoyment exists independently of rent or that minor/cured tenant defaults do not excuse the landlord’s statutory obligations. Instead, Quirico emphasizes that a tenant who fails to comply with G.L. c. 239, § 8A can still be evicted for nonpayment and suggests (in dicta) that the landlord may evict notwithstanding alleged code violations. The passage therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated about G.L. c. 186, § 14 or quiet enjoyment’s independence from rent obligations.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The situation before us is that tenants who have admittedly withheld payment of rent for apartments which they continued to occupy despite alleged violations of the Code now take the position that by reason of the violations the landlord may neither evict them nor recover any rent from them. The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code.”
